features.popup:
Syukhtun

Modern: Santa Barbara · Division: Barbareño · Pop: ~1,000
Coastal — Mission Creek, lagoons
The capital village of the Chumash world — one of the largest settlements on the Pacific Coast. Population up to 1,000. Located where downtown Santa Barbara stands today. The name lives on as the Chumash name for the Santa Barbara area. A political center with hereditary chief (wot) who had authority over several surrounding settlements. Each large village had a ceremonial dance ground enclosed by a tule-mat windbreak, a sweathouse ('apa'yik), and a sacred enclosure (siliyik) where priests conducted rituals. Mission Santa Barbara (1786) was built facing the Channel Islands from this village's territory.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Mishopshno

Modern: Carpinteria · Division: Barbareño · Pop: ~600-800
Carpinteria Salt Marsh, tar seeps
Major coastal village at present-day Carpinteria. In the creation story, the rainbow bridge (wishtoyo) from Limuw (Santa Cruz Island) landed at Tzchimoos, the tall mountain near Mishopshno. The Carpinteria tar seeps were essential to Chumash life — asphaltum (bitumen) was used to waterproof tomol canoes, baskets, and tools. Spanish soldiers named the area 'La Carpinteria' (the carpentry shop) after watching Chumash build tomol canoes here. The salt marsh provided rich habitat for shorebirds, fish, and shellfish.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Helo

Modern: Goleta / UCSB area · Division: Barbareño · Pop: ~500
Goleta Slough / coastal lagoon
Village on the coast south of Goleta, near present-day UCSB. The Goleta Slough was a major food source — rich in fish, shellfish, and waterfowl. One of several villages around the productive Goleta marshlands. Related villages: Elhiman and Alwatalam (in the Goleta marsh), Sahpilil (coast SW of Goleta).
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Mikiw

Modern: Dos Pueblos (western village) · Division: Barbareño · Pop: ~800
Coastal — Naples Reef offshore
One of the 'Two Pueblos' — two Chumash villages side by side that Cabrillo documented in 1542, giving us the oldest European place name in Goleta. Portolá's 1769 expedition estimated 60 houses and 800 people. Mikiw and neighboring Kuyamu thrived because of the abundant Naples Reef just offshore. The people of Mikiw were said to be tall, slender, and light-complexioned — though modern historians question this oral tradition from Rosa Den Welch (1875). 227 years passed between Cabrillo's visit and the next European contact (Portolá 1769).
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Kuyamu

Modern: Dos Pueblos (eastern village) · Division: Barbareño · Pop: ~600
Coastal — Naples Reef offshore
The second of the 'Two Pueblos.' Fr. Crespi described 'an Indian settlement of no less than 600 souls.' The Portolá expedition camped near Kuyamu and was immediately greeted with gifts of fresh fish. The Chumash 'had been welcomed at most every village since Malibu and were growing weary of the all-night parties.'
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Amolomol

Modern: near Montecito · Division: Barbareño
Coastal — near Montecito Creek
Coastal village between Syukhtun and Mishopshno. One of the many settlements that lined the Santa Barbara Channel coast, spaced every 1-2 miles.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Onomyo

Modern: Gaviota · Division: Barbareño/Purisimeño border
Gaviota Creek, Gaviota Hot Springs
Village at Gaviota. An important village not mentioned by Cabrillo but archaeologically confirmed. Nearby Anawupu was on a small stream emptying into the Pacific at Gaviota. Gaviota Hot Springs were sacred waters used for healing.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Elhelel

Modern: East of Santa Barbara · Division: Barbareño
Coastal
Coastal village east of Santa Barbara. Part of the dense chain of settlements lining the Channel coast.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Mismatuk

Modern: Arroyo Burro / Santa Barbara · Division: Barbareño
Arroyo Burro creek
Village in Arroyo Burro near Santa Barbara Mission. Located on one of the many small creeks draining the Santa Ynez Mountains to the coast.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Shisholop

Modern: Ventura (San Buenaventura) · Division: Ventureño · Pop: ~500-800
Ventura River mouth, coastal
Major village at the mouth of the Ventura River. The Chumash name for the river system. Mission San Buenaventura (1782) was established here — the last mission founded personally by Fr. Serra. Related village: Chikachkach at the actual river mouth.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Saticoy (Saaqtikoy)

Modern: Saticoy · Division: Ventureño
Santa Clara River
Village on the Santa Clara River. The name means 'it is sheltered from the wind' in Ventureño. Harrington's informants described beaver at Saticoy: 'The beaver builds its house in the river or the cienegas in the time of our ancestors. There were beavers at Ventura and also at Saticoy.'
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Sespe (Seqpe)

Modern: near Fillmore · Division: Ventureño
Sespe Creek — free-flowing wild trout stream
Village on Sespe Creek, near Camulos. The name means 'kneecap' in Ventureño. Sespe Creek remains one of the last free-flowing significant streams in southern California. The Sespe Wilderness (1992) protects condor habitat in the headwaters.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Piru (Piru)

Modern: Piru · Division: Ventureño
Piru Creek (Santa Clara tributary)
Village on Piru Creek. Santa Felicia Dam (1955) forms Lake Piru, blocking steelhead. During the Gold Rush, miners used routes through Chumash territory from Santa Barbara to gold diggings on Piru Creek.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Castaic (Katq)

Modern: Castaic · Division: Ventureño
Castaic Creek (Santa Clara tributary)
Village at present-day Castaic Lake area. The name means 'the eye, the face' in Ventureño. Castaic Creek is a major Santa Clara River tributary draining the Liebre Mountains.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Camulos (Kamulus)

Modern: Camulos Ranch · Division: Ventureño
Santa Clara River
Village on the Santa Clara River. The name means 'the juniper' in Ventureño. Rancho Camulos, a National Historic Landmark, preserves the site. The ranch was the inspiration for Helen Hunt Jackson's novel Ramona (1884).
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Humaliwo

Modern: Malibu · Division: Ventureño
Malibu Creek / Malibu Lagoon
The village that gives us Malibu — meaning 'where the surf sounds loudly' in Ventureño. Cultural remains date to 7,000 years old. Listed on the National Register (1976). Cabrillo anchored here in 1542 and named it 'Pueblo de las Canoas' (Town of the Canoes). Neighboring villages: ta'lopop (Malibu Canyon), Sumo (Point Dume/Zuma — 'abundance'), Loxostox'ni (Lechuza Canyon), Hipuk (Westlake Village). Humaliwo was a landing site for ti'at plank canoes from Catalina Island (Tongva territory). Point Mugu (Muwu — 'beach') was a tomol launching site for the half-day crossing to Santa Cruz Island.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Muwu

Modern: Point Mugu · Division: Ventureño
Mugu Lagoon — rich tidelands
Village at the mouth of Mugu Lagoon. The name means 'beach' in Ventureño. A launching site for tomol canoes making the half-day passage to Santa Cruz Island. Trails connected the lagoon tidelands to villages in La Jolla Valley. Now within Naval Air Weapons Station Point Mugu.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Hueneme (Wenemu)

Modern: Port Hueneme · Division: Ventureño
Coastal
Village at present-day Port Hueneme. The name means 'sleeping place' in Ventureño. One of the coastal villages between Mugu and Ventura.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Simi (Imiyi)

Modern: Simi Valley · Division: Ventureño
Arroyo Simi / Simi Hills springs
Inland village in the Simi Valley. The meaning of the name is uncertain. Burro Flats Painted Cave, the globally significant solstice-marking rock art site, is in the Simi Hills nearby.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Ojai (Awhay)

Modern: Ojai · Division: Ventureño
Ventura River / San Antonio Creek
Village in the Ojai Valley. The name means 'moon' in Ventureño. The Ojai Valley sits at the heart of the Ventura River watershed — 100% dependent on local water, no imports. Matilija Creek, the main Ventura River tributary, drains from the Matilija Wilderness through this valley.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Matilija (Matilha)

Modern: Matilija Canyon · Division: Ventureño
Matilija Creek — dammed (1947)
Village on Matilija Creek. The name may mean 'division' in the Ojai dialect of Ventureño. A ranchería under Mission San Buenaventura. Chumash collected dogbane (Apocynum cannabinum) from these canyons for fiber, and harvested pitch and nuts from pine trees. Matilija Dam (1947) — built against Army Corps advice — is now slated for removal.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Nupu

Modern: Santa Paula · Division: Ventureño
Santa Paula Creek / Santa Clara River
Village at present-day Santa Paula, on the Santa Clara River.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Somis (Soms)

Modern: Somis · Division: Ventureño
springs
Village near Ojai. The name means 'scrub-oak spring' in Ventureño. The spring-fed water source encoded in the name itself tells us why this village was here.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Soxtonocmu'

Modern: Santa Ynez Valley · Division: Ineseño (Samala)
Santa Ynez River / Zanja de Cota Creek
Dominant polity of the inland Chumash network (Santa Ynez Valley). The political center that controlled subsidiary villages including Hawamiw. Located near the modern town of Santa Ynez, where the Santa Ynez Reservation (127 acres) is the homeland of the only federally recognized Chumash tribe.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Cachuma (Aqicum)

Modern: Cachuma area (now under Lake Cachuma) · Division: Ineseño (Samala)
Santa Ynez River / Cachuma Creek — NOW INUNDATED
Village in Cachuma Canyon. The name is said to mean 'a constant sign' in Ineseño. This village site is now under Lake Cachuma, inundated when Bradbury Dam was completed in 1953. The dam 'obliterated thousands of years of Chumash culture.' The modern lake and county park bear the village's name.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Jonata (Xonxoni'ata)

Modern: near Los Olivos · Division: Ineseño/Purisimeño
Santa Ynez River tributaries
Village near present-day Los Olivos. The name means 'tall oak' in Purisimeño. Modern Rancho San Fernando Rey (Jonata Ranch) preserves the name.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Stuke (Stuk)

Modern: Stuke Canyon, E of Santa Ynez · Division: Ineseño (Samala)
Santa Ynez River tributary
Village in a canyon east of Santa Ynez. The name means 'wooden bowl' in Ineseño.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Tequepis (Teqeq)

Modern: Tequepis Canyon / Lake Cachuma · Division: Ineseño (Samala)
Tequepis Creek / Santa Ynez River
Village in Tequepis Canyon, south of Lake Cachuma. Meaning uncertain. Cachuma County Park is located near Tequepis Point today.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Onohwi

Modern: near Nojoqui Falls · Division: Ineseño (Samala)
Nojoqui Creek (Santa Ynez tributary)
Village on Nojoqui Creek, a branch of the Santa Ynez River. Nojoqui Falls, a 164-foot waterfall, is one of the most beautiful water features in Chumash territory.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Lompoc (Lompo)

Modern: Lompoc · Division: Purisimeño
Santa Ynez River (lower)
Village near present-day Lompoc. The name may mean 'in the cheeks' or 'stagnant water / lagoon' in Purisimeño. Mission La Purísima Concepción (1787) was established nearby. Site of the 1824 Chumash Revolt — warriors occupied the mission for a month before Mexican soldiers retook it.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Nipomo (Nipumu)

Modern: Nipomo · Division: Purisimeño/Obispeño
Nipomo Creek
Village at present-day Nipomo. May mean 'village' in Obispeño or 'at the promontory' in Purisimeño.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Sisquoc (Asuskwa)

Modern: Sisquoc River · Division: Purisimeño
Sisquoc River — free-flowing
Village or campsite on the Sisquoc River. The name is said to mean 'stopping place' in Purisimeño. The modern name applies to the river itself — 50 miles, free-flowing, one of the wildest rivers in southern California.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Halam

Modern: Jalama Beach · Division: Purisimeño
Jalama Creek — coastal
Village on Jalama Creek near the coast. The name means 'bundle' in Purisimeño. Jalama Beach remains one of the most remote and undeveloped beaches in Santa Barbara County.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Zaca (Asaka)

Modern: Zaca Station / Los Olivos · Division: Purisimeño
Zaca Creek (Santa Ynez tributary)
Village at Zaca Station. The name means 'in the bed' in Purisimeño. Zaca Creek joins the Santa Ynez River north of Buellton. The wine country of the Santa Ynez Valley occupies this ancient Chumash landscape.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Pedernales ('Anokio)

Modern: Point Pedernales · Division: Purisimeño
Coastal
Village at Point Pedernales on the coast. Now within Vandenberg Space Force Base. The Kagismuwas Chumash had their historical lands in this area.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Pismu

Modern: Pismo Beach · Division: Obispeño
Pismo Creek / coastal
Village near present-day Pismo Beach. The name means 'tar' in Obispeño — referring to the natural asphaltum seeps that were vital to Chumash technology.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Kasmali

Modern: Casmalia · Division: Purisimeño
near San Antonio Creek
Village near present-day Casmalia. The name means 'it is the last' in Purisimeño — suggesting it was the last village in a chain along the coast or a route.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Tecuya (Takuy)

Modern: Tecuya Creek · Division: Emigdiano
Tecuya Creek
Village on Tecuya Creek, west of Tejon. The name may mean 'holding' in Ventureño. One of three Emigdiano villages at canyon apertures with marriage ties connecting the interior network. The Tecuya Chumash were established as an anti-colonial group during the mission period.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Matapuan

Modern: San Emigdio Hills · Division: Emigdiano
San Emigdio Creek
Emigdiano village at a canyon aperture in the San Emigdio Hills. Marriage ties connected Matapuan, Tashlipun, and Tecuya to the larger Emigdiano network centered on K'o'owhsup. Located near the Wind Wolves Preserve, home to the Pleito and Three Springs rock art sites with their extraordinary blue pigments.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Tashlipun

Modern: San Emigdio Hills · Division: Emigdiano
San Emigdio area creeks
Emigdiano village adjacent to Matapuan. Part of the interior network of villages at canyon apertures controlling access between the San Joaquin Valley and the mountain passes.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Kuyam

Modern: Cuyama Valley · Division: Cuyama
Cuyama River
Village on the Cuyama River. The word may relate to 'to rest, wait' in Ineseño — perhaps a resting place on the route between the coast and interior. Gives us the modern name Cuyama. Grant recorded 41 painted rock art sites in the Cuyama Valley region.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Limuw villages (11 sites)

Modern: Santa Cruz Island · Division: Island Chumash · Pop: ~2,000+ total
Island springs and seasonal creeks
Limuw — 'in the sea' — Santa Cruz Island, the largest of the Channel Islands. 11 village sites identified. In the creation story, Hutash (Earth Mother) created the first Chumash people here. When the island grew crowded, she built a rainbow bridge to the mainland. Key villages: Ch'oloshush (west end — 'a group of sea birds'), Xaxas (major village — NPS documented), Liyam ('to descend' — where creeks funneled together), Nanawani ('sky/up/above'), Lu'upsh ('put it in' — a canoe landing place). Shell bead money ('achum) was minted here using olivella shells and Santa Cruz Island chert drills — the currency of the Chumash economy.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Wima villages (8 sites)

Modern: Santa Rosa Island (Wimaɬ) · Division: Island Chumash · Pop: ~1,000+
Limited springs — seasonal
Wimaɬ — Santa Rosa Island. 8 village sites identified. Key villages: Nawani (west coast), Niakla (north coast), Nila'Ihuyu (south coast), Niimkulkiil (near west end). Arlington Springs on this island yielded human remains dating to 13,000+ years — among the oldest in North America. Phil Orr's pioneering radiocarbon dating work in the 1940s-60s established the deep antiquity of Channel Islands occupation.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Tuqan villages (2 sites)

Modern: San Miguel Island · Division: Island Chumash
Very limited — harsh conditions
Tuqan — San Miguel Island. 2 village sites identified. The most remote and windswept of the Channel Islands. Continuous occupation from 8,000-11,000 years ago documented by archaeological sites. Cabrillo died here in 1543 and was buried on the island — making it also a site of the first European death in Alta California.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Anyapax

Modern: Anacapa Island · Division: Island Chumash
NO consistent water source
Anyapax — said to mean 'mirage, illusion' in Ventureño. The smallest inhabited island. Likely used seasonally due to lack of a consistent water source — the Chumash understood that water determined where you could live. The modern spelling 'Anacapa' is due to an early cartographer's error.
Sources: Johnson 1988; Applegate 1974; King 1969; Harrington; NPS

Chumash Placenames Still Surviving

Over 40 Chumash placenames survive as the names of rivers, creeks, canyons, mountains, and towns across their territory. The correspondence between the original name and its modern equivalent is seldom exact, but the linguistic DNA of the Chumash world persists in the landscape:

Malibu (Humaliwo) — 'where the surf sounds loudly'
Ojai (Awhay) — 'moon'
Cuyama (Kuyam) — 'to rest, wait'
Pismo (Pismu) — 'tar'
Lompoc (Lompo) — 'stagnant water / lagoon'
Castaic (Katq) — 'the eye, the face'
Saticoy (Saaqtikoy) — 'sheltered from the wind'
Sespe (Seqpe) — 'kneecap'
Simi (Imiyi) — meaning unknown
Anacapa (Anyapax) — 'mirage, illusion'
Port Hueneme (Wenemu) — 'sleeping place'
Point Mugu (Muwu) — 'beach'
Nipomo (Nipumu) — 'village'
Somis (Soms) — 'scrub-oak spring'
Camulos (Kamulus) — 'the juniper'
Jalama (Xalam) — 'bundle'
Matilija (Matilha) — 'division'
Sources: Applegate 1974, 1975; internationalphoneticalphabet.org
